message.content: {"id": "47910", "title": "Bug 47910: ajc outjar jarfile does not contain MANIFEST.MF", "description": "When calling ajc with the parameters sourceroots <mydir outjar <my.jar, an output file with a .jar extension is created. However, this file is not a valid jar file because it does not contain a MANIFEST.MF file. The documentation for ajc suggests that outjar should create a zip file, but it does not make sense for a parameter called outjar to create a zip file.", "OB": "When using the outjar parameter, the resulting file does not contain a MANIFEST.MF file, making it an invalid jar file.", "EB": "If the outjar parameter is used, the resulting file should be a valid jar file and include the MANIFEST.MF file.", "SR": "The ajc compiler should generate a valid jar file with the MANIFEST.MF file when the outjar parameter is used."}

origin.input_prompt:
Your role is a senior software engineer, you are very good at analyzing and writing bug reports.
It is possible that the bug report may lack sufficient details in the OB, EB, and SR sections.  In such cases, your task is to infer the appropriate details based on the context and supplement the bug report to ensure it contains clear and complete OB/EB/SR statements.  Also, improve the wording of these statements for clarity where possible.
To facilitate this process, please provide your responses in JSON format as follows:
{"id": "", "title": "", "description": "", "OB": "", "EB": "", "SR": ""}
origin.input_content:
<BUG REPORT>
{'id': '47910', 'title': 'Bug 47910ajc outjar jarfile does not contain MANIFEST.MF', 'description': 'with a METAINF/MANIFEST.MFfile inside. ', 'OB': "Bug 47910ajc outjar jarfile does not contain MANIFEST.MF I call ajc sourceroots <mydir outjar <my.jar and an output file is createdwith a .jar extension, but it is not a valid jar file because there is noMANIFEST.MF file. I see that the text for ajc says:outjar <fileput output classes in zip file <filewhich might imply that it is supposed to be a zip file, but a parameter called outjar which creates a zip file doesn't really make sense. ", 'EB': 'If outjar is used,the resulting file should be a valid jar file, i.e. ', 'SR': ''}
